name: Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword
description: The standalone expansion for Mount & Blade! With Fire & Sword builds and expands upon the highly regarded combat system from Mount & Blade: Warband. Firearms have been introduced to the battlefield.

Here's the thing - if you're looking for the best mount & blade to buy and can only afford one of them, this is, sadly, not the choice to make. I love this game but Warband is the superior one, although this one has guns for the campaign, the gameplay is better and warband and there's just not anything new here. I enjoy both of the games, but this game does lack in comparison.   Now is it a bad game? Hell no. I love using a two-handed claymore one minute and switching to a pistol for the next wave of enemies, and having a group of 100 men with nearly all of them using muskets is so satisfying when you can watch them shoot down the entire enemy group. If you can afford both mount and blades grab both of them, and while you'll throw more hours into the other, you'll get a great amount of game time and fun from this one as well to make your purchase worth it. Just wait for a sell first.

It is a very good expansion to the Mount & Blade series! Although the Napoleonic Wars DLC trumps this one in popularity, it is still worth the money to buy this DLC.  The Multiplayer has very few players (One or two active servers with a few dozen people) and in my opinion is ok compared to Native M&B Warband. However, there is no focus on ranged over hand-to-hand combat as both are used no matter your preference. There's archery, musketry, swords, shields, spears, crossbows, etc., etc.  The part I really like is the Singleplayer campaign, despite it being similar to the other DLCs. I just have a liking to this one in particular over the others for some reason, probably the guns (Since Mount & Blade Vanilla and Native Mount & Blade Warband don't have guns :D)  If you've played another Mount & Blade game or like Medieval and/or historical games, here's another one for the collection! It's a Mount and Blade game. Need I saw more? This entire series is a masterpiece. Great story, amazing gameplay, easy to learn - hard to master. Almost everything in this game is perfect. I prefer the 1600s setting over Napoleonic Wars. But like other great games - it's only good because the positives overlay the negatives. By god, there's a lot of them. - Crashes: The game crashes often. It's not really a graphics issue, it happens when interacting with an NPC. Even still, without crashing, clicking dialouge options often drops FPS waay low. - Hit Detection: Guns are the main selling point of this game. And they suck. More often than not, bullets go straight through enemies. Trying to hit anything below the abdomen is a surefire miss. - Siege: Sieges 'glitch' out a lot. Once you've pushed pass the wall, you head down to engage the enemy... and there's an invisible wall! The AI just sits back behind this wall - none of your soldiers can hit them, they don't charge, and you can only use what's left of bullets/arrows to take them out. Then retreat, loose morale and have your soldiers suck even more. - AI: They can be stupid sometimes. AI is hard to program - I don't blame 'em. - Music: The music is buggy as hell and likes to-o r-r-r-re-n-n-ot-t-tesic-c-ch is an-n-n-nin-ng as h-e-e-e-ell. (to repeat notes which is annoying as hell)  Don't let these cons fool you - this game is amazing. However, some players may get annoyed by these glitches, so be cautious

A very different game from the previous Mount & Blade games. Some changes not so good. But the biggest good, or interesting change at least, is the addition of firearms. It really changes how combat works, especially early on it can be quite difficult. It definitely provides a new experience and I think it is worth trying. Really changes the combat. I think in terms of whether that change is good or not, will differ greatly from person to person.   If I had to choose my top Mount & Blade game it would be Warband. This one has removed the arenas and tournaments from the game, which I think they should have kept. However this is still a fun game, and the other changes make it worth trying out.

Good game. It's economical aspect is much better than Warband who had basically no economy.  I wish the economy of the game would reflect the income and resources a lord has. That way, commerce would be even more interesting, and being a bandit even more fun as caravans would transport important supplies.  Combat, as in all M&B, is excellent. Adding firearms only adds another dimension to the already excellent combat system.  It would be nice if the designer could make a gameworld as good as their game system. Right now, few gameworlds were interesting enough to hook me more than a dozen hours each. I lose interest in M&B games due to the bland game worlds. I don't mind having no story if I have something to do in the game world like trading, building, patrolling, hunting, marrying, spying, conquering, diplomacy, politics, economics, road building, bridge building, cult-related stuff, etc. There are very few of these things you can do in all M&B games put together. I really thing they should improve the game worlds they use, they are too colourless.  Still, it's a must buy for anyone who dreamed since the 1980s of having a game where you can fight on horseback in real time, not some dumb swings of weapons on horse back, real fighting with some physics involved.

An RPG set in the medieval era...aren't they all? But I digress. Mount and blade with fire and sword is a fairly good RPG. If you were to imagine total war on a smaller scale where you play as one of the soldiers, this is it. You start a new game, make a new character and set off on your journey. you can use bows, swords, shields and guns. Bows will lose accuracy the longer you aim them and because the guns are muskets they have little to no accuracy from a distance. You will wander around the campaign map doing quests for kingdoms pillaging villages and battling people. you can recruit mercenaries to help you in your adventures or recruit random people from pubs. You upgrade there equipment and will eventually have a force large enough to take over a castle. These battles are large and hard to win but when you do win the spoils are awesome. BUY THIS GAME.

Excellent game, expansion of Mount & Blade: Warband that includes guns, grenades, and more. If you haven't played Mount & Blade: Warband yet, I highly suggest you go there first. This game serves more as an expansion on Warband.  Pros: interesting and indepth war based in central and eastern europe, at the outbreak of gunpowder warfare. Firearms add a new depth to battle situations, and allow for more strategy when controlling your units. Seige mechanics have been greatly improved (mostly in the fact that not everyone is trying to cram themselves onto ONE ladder to seige the castle), including more diverse town and fortress layouts. Multiplayer is improved again with better seige battles, and the popular survival-squad type game mode.  Cons: Does take a while to get going and have a decent sized army. Certain units are greatly overpowered (looking at you Swedish Reiters). Unable to buy stores and businesses in this version, and weapon diversity is down from the last game.  Overall, excellent niche game for those who have played games such as Total War or Age of Empires, and have wanted to experience personal action on the battlefield, or if you like Chivalry, try your hand at commanding your forces.

An interesting if somewhat poorly handled official mod, With Fire & Sword is actually Mount & Blade's official release in Poland, pretty much setting up history from the 16th century or so as a framing device. One thing that becomes immediately clearis that this version of Mount & Blade is MUCH harder than its previous incarnations. This can be summed up in three simple reasons: poorer economy, less effective armor, and GUNS. The regional economy is falling on hard times and defeating even bandit infantry is much more difficult than is thanks to the fact that much of your armor is cloth and even low level enemies will carry rifles. Soloing is nearly impossible, so you will have to amass an army one way or another soon. If you're the kind of person who likes to just roam the map being a lone wolf, this is not the game for you, but if you enjoy building up a (surprisingly historically accurate) army and inflicting it on your fellow man, give With Fire & Sword a shot. Mount & Blade: WFaS is an awesome game that combines the amazing gameplay from Warband with a twist of gunpowder, this minor addition alters the whole game darastically.   This game is hard at first, it requires correct judgment of reach and speed whilst also challenging you to think about what direction to attack from. You can attack and parry from 4 sides, slash/parry from left, slash/parry from right, slash/parry overhead attacks as well as stab. The controls are very simple, a simple click and flick of the mouse in a particular direction will give you your attack/parry.   The gameplay in this game is a mix of RPG, Strategy and Action, you will be controlling a main character, leveling them up and giving them weapons and armour. When you are in combat you will also be commanding an army (if you have decided to recruit troops) the commands are very simple, such as; hold, move up, charge and hold fire (with fire and sword feature only).  In short this game has given me hours of fun.

Mount and Blade is an addictive game where you go about trading and fighting on foot or horseback. Your character upgrades itself as you gain experience. Buy, collect or sell weapons, armour, firearms (Pistols, Muskets, Grenades), different kind of horses, sell prisoners as slaves, recruit troops, etc. The mechanics of fighting is the best part of the game. There are even seiges you can take part in to storm a castle.   Fire and Sword is based more heavily on trading than the original version and here are many more castles, and a bigger map. You can even send caravans to trade and in this version, this provides substantial money. Castles and towns can also be developed quite a bit after you own them. You can even order hand-crafted weapons at a steep price and which are slightly better than what you find on the market.   Great game!

The most satisfying thing in this game is when an enemy is running at you and you aim your pistol at his face and blast him away right before he reaches you. And also running over people with a big horsey :)  On a more serious note, I highly recommend this game if you are the least bit interested in sword combat and a hint of strategy and controlling your own conquering army. The neat thing about this game is that while you can look at a map and move your army around the continent, and choose castles and villages to raid or conquer, as soon as you begin a battle, you have the option to join it. Which means you have your own character that you level up and equip gear to who serves as your army's leader. So there is both a strategic side as well as a medieval FPS side. In my opinion it also has a very good replay value.   All in all it's a very well made game and I have enjoyed all 400+ hours of gameplay :)
